    <item>
      <title>US navy strips officer of command over capture of 10 sailors by Iran</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2016/may/13/us-navy-strips-officer-of-command-over-capture-of-10-sailors-by-iran</link>
      <description><p> Group wandered into Iranian territorial waters in the Persian Gulf and were held for 15 hours before intervention by US secretary of state secured release</p><p>A US navy officer has been stripped of his command over the capture by Iran of 10 American sailors who <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/world/2016/jan/12/iran-detains-two-us-navy-ships-persian-gulf">wandered into its territorial waters</a>.</p><p>In a statement on Thursday the navy said it had lost confidence in Commander Eric Rasch, who was the executive officer of the squadron that included the 10 sailors at the time of the January incident. He was responsible for the training and readiness of the more than 400 sailors in the unit.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2016/may/13/us-navy-strips-officer-of-command-over-capture-of-10-sailors-by-iran">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <title>Amazon 'getting away with murder on tax', says Donald Trump</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2016/may/13/amazon-getting-away-with-on-tax-says-donald-trump</link>
      <description><p>The online retailer has a ‘huge antitrust problem’, says the Republican, and accuses founder Jeff Bezos of using the Washington Post for political influence </p><p>Donald Trump has launched a frontal assault on Amazon.com, the world’s biggest online retailer, saying it has “a huge antitrust problem”.</p><p> <span>Related: </span><a href="https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2016/may/12/paul-ryan-donald-trump-republican-unity-battle">Paul Ryan and Donald Trump might say they're unified. But there's a bloody civil war on | Richard Wolffe</a> </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2016/may/13/amazon-getting-away-with-on-tax-says-donald-trump">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Trump and Ryan: meeting was a 'very positive step' toward GOP unity – as it happened</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/live/2016/may/12/us-election-live-trump-paul-ryan-meeting</link>
      <description><ul><li>Presumptive nominee and congressional leaders meet on Capitol Hill</li><li>‘I want to be part of the unifying process,’ House speaker has said</li><li><a href="http://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2016/may/12/moderate-republicans-donald-trump-hillary-clinton">Take it or leave it: Trump’s rise puts GOP moderates in tough corner</a></li><li><a href="http://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2016/may/12/911-commission-saudi-arabia-hijackers">Saudi officials were supporting 9/11 hijackers, commission member says</a></li></ul><p class="block-time published-time"> <time datetime="2016-05-13T02:25:12.656Z">3.25am <span class="timezone">BST</span></time> </p><p>Can’t we all just get along?</p><p class="block-time published-time"> <time datetime="2016-05-13T02:11:35.565Z">3.11am <span class="timezone">BST</span></time> </p><p>Facebook CEO Mark Zuckerberg has announced that he plans to “invit[e] leading conservatives and people from across the political spectrum” to talk with him about accusations of political bias at the social media company.</p><p> <span>Related: </span><a href="https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2016/may/12/zuckerberg-denies-facebook-bias-invites-conservatives-talk">Zuckerberg invites top conservatives to talk and denies Facebook bias</a> </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/live/2016/may/12/us-election-live-trump-paul-ryan-meeting">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Police could lose public funds if officers aren't trained to best avoid shootings</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2016/may/12/police-shootings-bill-us-house-gwen-moore</link>
      <description><p>US bill would financially penalize police chiefs who don’t order and train officers to do everything possible to avoid open fire during confrontations with suspects</p><p>Police departments across the US would lose public funding if they fail to introduce tighter restrictions on when their officers may shoot at suspects under a new law proposed by a Democratic congresswoman.<br></p><p>A bill due to be introduced in the House of Representatives on Thursday by Gwen Moore of Wisconsin would financially penalize any police chiefs who did not order and train their officers to do everything possible to avoid opening fire during confrontations with suspects.<br></p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2016/may/12/police-shootings-bill-us-house-gwen-moore">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Alabama governor signs bill to regulate abortion clinics like sex offenders</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2016/may/12/alabama-abortion-clinics-schools-sex-offenders-bill</link>
      <description><p>Law mandates clinics be more than 2,000ft from public schools serving preteens and could force closure of two clinics that serve majority of state’s women</p><p>Alabama’s Republican governor, Robert Bentley, signed a bill into law on Thursday that will regulate abortion clinics like sex offenders.</p><p>The bill, SB 205, could shut down two clinics in which the vast majority of the state’s abortions occur. One of the clinics, Alabama Women’s Center for Reproductive Alternatives in Huntsville, was temporarily <a href="http://www.al.com/news/huntsville/index.ssf/2014/10/3_12_months_after_closing_nort.html">closed in June 2014 as a result of Trap</a> (targeted restriction on abortion provider) laws in the state when it was determined that the facility could not be retrofitted to comply with the laws’ building code regulations. Its new building, however, sits across the street from Huntsville’s Academy for Academics and Arts, a K-8 school, making it vulnerable once again to shutdown under the newly signed law. </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2016/may/12/alabama-abortion-clinics-schools-sex-offenders-bill">Continue reading...</a></description>
      <category domain="https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/alabama">Alabama</category>

      <category domain="https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/us-news">US news</category>
      <category domain="https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/women">Women</category>
      <pubDate>Thu, 12 May 2016 22:11:31 GMT</pubDate>
      <guid>https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2016/may/12/alabama-abortion-clinics-schools-sex-offenders-bill</guid>
      <media:content width="140" url="https://i.guim.co.uk/img/media/74b2754b6c480113ca431cad77f803ee0c9fe028/0_190_5590_3356/5590.jpg?w=140&q=55&auto=format&usm=12&fit=max&s=152e63db49519609dac835d0cb237141">
        <media:credit scheme="urn:ebu">Photograph: Max Blau for the Guardian</media:credit>
      </media:content>
      <media:content width="460" url="https://i.guim.co.uk/img/media/74b2754b6c480113ca431cad77f803ee0c9fe028/0_190_5590_3356/5590.jpg?w=460&q=55&auto=format&usm=12&fit=max&s=9ed3d8dd1cdc5fe85c8f7de483baddc2">
        <media:credit scheme="urn:ebu">Photograph: Max Blau for the Guardian</media:credit>
      </media:content>
      <dc:creator>Jennifer Gerson Uffalussy in Atlanta</dc:creator>

    <item>
      <title>George Zimmerman's gun used to kill Trayvon Martin back up for auction</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2016/may/12/george-zimmerman-gun-trayvon-martin-gun-auction-website-removed</link>
      <description><p>Handgun, which Zimmerman calls a ‘piece of American history’, reappears on firearms site after it was pulled from GunBroker.com amid widespread criticism</p><p>An attempt by <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/us-news/george-zimmerman">George Zimmerman</a> to auction the gun he used to kill Trayvon Martin in 2012 appeared to be back on again Thursday following an extraordinary day in which the owner of the first website on which the weapon first appeared took down the listing, saying he wanted no part of the controversial sale.</p><p>Billed as “your opportunity to own a piece of American history”, Zimmerman’s listing abruptly disappeared from GunBroker.com shortly after the auction’s advertised 11am ET start time. The former neighbourhood watch volunteer, who was acquitted three years ago over the death of the unarmed black teenager in Sanford, Florida – a case that sparked protests and a national debate about race relations – was seeking at least $5,000 for the gun.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2016/may/12/george-zimmerman-gun-trayvon-martin-gun-auction-website-removed">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <title>Trump calls DC Republicans to heel</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/live/2016/may/12/donald-trump-washington-republicans-paul-ryan-unity</link>
      <description><p>Got a minute? Trump sweeps through capital … leaves behind coos of ‘unity’... and everything else you need to know today from the campaign trail. By Tom McCarthy</p><p class="block-time published-time"> <time datetime="2016-05-12T20:38:03.639Z">9.38pm <span class="timezone">BST</span></time> </p><p>They called him an albatross. They called him a fake. They literally called him crazy. But on Thursday, Republicans in congress found another title for Donald Trump: boss.</p><p><a href="http://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2016/may/12/donald-trump-paul-ryan-meeting-washington-republicans-election">Ryan: ‘It’s important we don’t fake unifying’</a></p><p class="block-time published-time"> <time datetime="2016-05-12T20:38:02.006Z">9.38pm <span class="timezone">BST</span></time> </p><p>Trump held meetings with top GOP brass including speaker Paul Ryan, whose conservative convictions led him to express reservations about Trump just one week ago. </p><p><a href="http://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2016/may/12/donald-trump-campaign-replaces-five-potential-california-delegates">Trump replaces five potential delegates</a></p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/live/2016/may/12/donald-trump-washington-republicans-paul-ryan-unity">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <title>US immigration officials planning 30-day 'surge' of arrests to deport families</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2016/may/12/us-immigration-officials-deportation-surge-arrests</link>
      <description><p>May arrests to focus on Central American mothers and children who’ve already been told to leave, according to ICE internal document instructing field offices</p><p>US immigration officials are planning a month-long series of raids in May and June to deport <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2016/jan/13/central-american-migration-family-children-detention-at-us-border">hundreds of Central American mothers and children</a> found to have entered the country illegally, according to sources and an internal document seen by Reuters.</p><p> <span>Related: </span><a href="https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2016/may/04/lawsuit-texas-immigration-detention-facilities-family-centres">Lawsuit aims to stop licensing of Texas immigration detention facilities</a> </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2016/may/12/us-immigration-officials-deportation-surge-arrests">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Clinton Cash film aims to cause likely Democratic nominee maximum damage</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2016/may/12/clinton-cash-film-hillary-foundation-finances</link>
      <description><p>The makers of a film opening in Philadelphia during July’s party convention hope its scrutiny of Hillary Clinton’s finances will resonate with Sanders supporters</p><p>When delegates to the Democratic national convention gather in Philadelphia at the end of July to – almost certainly – nominate Hillary Clinton as their presidential candidate, they may be in for a bit of a surprise.       <title>US poultry workers wear diapers on job over lack of bathroom breaks – report</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2016/may/12/poultry-workers-wear-diapers-work-bathroom-breaks</link>
      <description><ul><li>Oxfam says many are afraid to ask for permission to go to the bathroom<br></li><li>One supplier calls allegations ‘troubling’ and refusal of breaks not tolerated<br></li></ul><p>A <a href="https://www.oxfamamerica.org/static/media/files/No_Relief_Embargo.pdf">report</a> from international advocacy group Oxfam says poultry workers in the United States labor in a “climate of fear”, with some forced to wear diapers on the job. </p><p> It says many workers are afraid to ask for permission to go to the bathroom. The report says a worker at a Simmons Foods plant in Arkansas told Oxfam that she and many others resorted to wearing diapers. A Tyson Foods worker says in the report that many workers at his North Carolina plant “have to urinate in their pants”.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2016/may/12/poultry-workers-wear-diapers-work-bathroom-breaks">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2016/may/12/zuckerberg-denies-facebook-bias-invites-conservatives-talk</link>
      <description><p>As Facebook battles a report accusing it of suppressing conservative news, CEO says he plans to ‘invite leading conservatives ... to share their point of view’</p><p>Facebook CEO Mark Zuckerberg has announced that he plans to invite “leading conservatives and people from across the political spectrum” to talk with him about accusations of political bias at the social media company.</p><p>Zuckerberg made the announcement Thursday evening in a <a href="https://www.facebook.com/zuck/posts/10102830259184701">Facebook post</a> that continued to deny the allegations of bias and the claim that the Facebook trending topics team suppresses conservative news. </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2016/may/12/zuckerberg-denies-facebook-bias-invites-conservatives-talk">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <description><ul><li>Hispanic mayor removed after making clear he does not back candidate</li><li>Republican party says its bylaws ‘supersede’ state deadline for delegate list</li></ul><p>Donald Trump’s campaign has replaced five potential members of its California delegation to the Republican National Convention, including a white nationalist, an anti-Muslim pastor, and the Mexican-American mayor of a southern California city who says that he takes offense at the presidential candidate’s anti-Mexican rhetoric. </p><p> <span>Related: </span><a href="https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2016/may/11/donald-trump-california-delegates-republican-convention">Reality stars and xenophobes: Trump's California delegates mirror their maker</a> </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2016/may/12/donald-trump-campaign-replaces-five-potential-california-delegates">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <title>Ryan on meeting with Trump: 'It’s important we don’t fake unifying'</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2016/may/12/donald-trump-paul-ryan-meeting-washington-republicans-election</link>
      <description><p>Paul Ryan and Donald Trump issued a joint statement after meeting in Washington Thursday, saying ‘we are totally committed to working together’</p><p>The Republican party was <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2016/may/12/moderate-republicans-donald-trump-hillary-clinton">struggling to heal its deep wounds</a> on Thursday, as House speaker Paul Ryan claimed he was “very encouraged” by his meeting with Donald Trump but again declined to endorse him.<br></p><p>In a series of <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2016/may/11/republicans-donald-trump-paul-ryan-party-unity">eagerly watched meetings</a> on Capitol Hill that drew placard-waving protesters and hundreds of reporters, the presumptive Republican nominee held peace talks with GOP leaders in a bid to unify around something more than hostility toward Hillary Clinton.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2016/may/12/donald-trump-paul-ryan-meeting-washington-republicans-election">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <description><p>Hillary Clinton, who has disclosed all personal tax returns since 1977, also said that Donald Trump’s tax plan is ‘written by a billionaire for billionaires’</p><p>Hillary Clinton has attacked Donald Trump for his refusal to release his tax returns, criticising the billionaire businessman at a campaign event.</p><p>“You have to ask yourself, why doesn’t he want to release them?” asked Clinton at a crowd at a community college gymnasium in Blackwood, New Jersey, on Wednesday, according to <a draggable="true" href="http://www.nytimes.com/2016/05/12/us/politics/hillary-clinton-donald-trump-tax-returns.html?em_pos=large&amp;emc=edit_nn_20160512&amp;nl=morning-briefing&amp;nlid=71564729&amp;_r=1">the New York Times</a>.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2016/may/12/hillary-clinton-donald-trump-tax-return">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Saudi officials were 'supporting' 9/11 hijackers, commission member says</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2016/may/12/911-commission-saudi-arabia-hijackers</link>
      <description><p>First serious public split revealed among commissioners over the release of the secret ‘28 pages’ that detail Saudi ties to 2001 terrorist attacks </p><p>A former Republican member of the 9/11 commission, breaking dramatically with the commission’s leaders, said Wednesday he believes there was clear evidence that Saudi government employees were part of a support network for the 9/11 hijackers and that the Obama administration should move quickly to declassify a long-secret congressional report on Saudi ties to the 2001 terrorist attack.</p><p> The comments by John F Lehman, an investment banker in New York who was Navy secretary in the Reagan administration, signal the first serious public split among the 10 commissioners since they issued a 2004 final report that was largely read as an exoneration of Saudi Arabia, which was home to 15 of the 19 hijackers on 9/11.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2016/may/12/911-commission-saudi-arabia-hijackers">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <category domain="https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/us-politics">US politics</category>
      <category domain="https://www.theguardian.com/world/middleeast">Middle East and North Africa</category>
      <category domain="https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/us-national-security">US national security</category>
      <category domain="https://www.theguardian.com/world/world">World news</category>

      <title>Malcolm Turnbull and Barack Obama discuss global glut in steel</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/business/2016/may/12/malcolm-turnbull-and-barack-obama-discuss-global-glut-in-steel</link>
      <description><p>‘It is important that the viability of steel makers in our country, and in the US and other nations, is preserved,’ PM says</p><p>Barack Obama and the Australian prime minister, Malcolm Turnbull, have discussed by telephone the global glut in steel supply, which many blame on chronic overcapacity at Chinese producers of the construction material. </p><p>China’s steel production hit a record high this year as rising prices, and profits, encouraged mills that had been shut or suspended to resume output. </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/business/2016/may/12/malcolm-turnbull-and-barack-obama-discuss-global-glut-in-steel">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/business/2016/may/11/workplace-injury-illness-online-labor-department</link>
      <description><p>The Department of Labor will require larger companies in high-risk sectors to supply information with the aim of driving up standards of workplace safety</p><p>Workers and the public will for the first time be able to go online to see details of employee injuries and illnesses – for instance, the number of broken ribs or amputations - at tens of thousands of American workplaces, under a new Labor Department rule announced on Thursday.</p><p> <span>Related: </span><a href="https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2016/mar/24/us-labor-department-new-union-busting-rule">US businesses attack new labor rule aimed at curbing union-busting tactics</a> </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/business/2016/may/11/workplace-injury-illness-online-labor-department">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Top 25 hedge fund managers earned $13bn in 2015 – more than some nations</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/business/2016/may/10/hedge-fund-managers-salaries-billions-kenneth-griffin-james-simon</link>
      <description><p>Top earners, Kenneth Griffin and James Simons, made $1.7bn each despite ‘hedge fund killing field’ on Wall Street where many companies lost billions or closed</p><p>The world’s top 25 hedge fund managers earned $13bn last year – more than<a href="http://databank.worldbank.org/data/download/GDP.pdf"> the entire economies of Namibia, the Bahamas or Nicaragua</a>.<br></p><p>Kenneth Griffin, founder and chief executive of Citadel, and James Simons, founder and chairman of Renaissance Technologies, shared the top spot, taking home $1.7bn each – equivalent to the annual salaries of 112,000 people taking home the US federal minimum wage of $15,080. </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/business/2016/may/10/hedge-fund-managers-salaries-billions-kenneth-griffin-james-simon">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <title>Donald Trump given a fighting chance by ailing US economy</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/business/2016/may/08/donald-trump-given-a-fighting-chance-by-ailing-us-economy-election-stock-market</link>
      <description><p>Millions of Americans think they have been left behind in the recovery and the billionaire has managed to tap into this discontent</p><p>The experts said it could never happen. There was no way in which Donald Trump could win the Republican nomination for the US presidency. Could a billionaire who had never held office, was distrusted by the party hierarchy, lacked a political machine and seemed to take delight in upsetting large chunks of the electorate really survive the primaries and have a shot at the White House? Well, really.</p><p>The smart money now says that Trump has no chance in a head-to-head presidential race with Hillary Clinton, who looks nailed-on as the candidate for the Democrats. Opinion polls suggest that Clinton would beat Trump by a margin of 10 percentage points were the election to be held now.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/business/2016/may/08/donald-trump-given-a-fighting-chance-by-ailing-us-economy-election-stock-market">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <title>US economy adds just 160,000 jobs in April – further sign of a slowdown</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/business/2016/may/06/april-jobs-report-us-economy-unemployment-rate</link>
      <description><p>Jobs figures were lower than predicted by economists with the percentage of the American labor force out of work holding steady at 5%<br></p><ul><li><a href="https://www.theguardian.com/business/live/2016/may/06/markets-nervously-await-us-jobs-report-business-live">Markets fall on shock US jobs report – business live</a></li></ul><p>The <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/business/useconomy">US economy</a> showed further signs of a slowdown on Friday as the US Department of Labor announced just 160,000 new jobs had been created in April, 40,000 fewer than had been expected. The US unemployment rate remained steady at 5%.</p><p>Economists surveyed by Reuters had expected the economy to add 202,000 jobs. February and March job gains were revised down, with the US economy now estimated to have added 19,000 jobs fewer than originally thought. </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/business/2016/may/06/april-jobs-report-us-economy-unemployment-rate">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <title>BT is just coasting with £6bn wave of broadband investment</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/business/nils-pratley-on-finance/2016/may/05/bt-6bn-wave-broadband-investment-coasting</link>
      <description><p>Some of the spending would have happened anyway and the plan will not represent a technological revolution</p><p>It’s a “further wave” of investment, <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/business/2016/may/05/bt-roll-out-superfast-broadband-4g-6bn-investment">says BT</a>, conjuring visions of Britain surfing to a fast-speed broadband future while other nations splash in the shallows. Don’t believe the hype: £6bn is a large sum, but not quite as it seems.</p><p>About a third probably covers newly arrived EE’s expansion of its 4G mobile network, which is spending that would have happened anyway. The Openreach broadband element – call it £4bn – equates to £1.33bn a year since this is a three-year programme. That’s an upgrade from a current rate of £1bn a year, but we’re not talking tsunamis.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/business/nils-pratley-on-finance/2016/may/05/bt-6bn-wave-broadband-investment-coasting">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>The Fed's new global mandate is not without risk</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/business/2016/may/05/us-federal-reserve-global-economy-interest-rate-rise</link>
      <description><p>If the US Federal Reserve feels beholden to financial markets, the risk of sharper rate hikes will increase</p><p>“There are only two tragedies in life,” Oscar Wilde <a href="http://www.gutenberg.org/files/790/790-h/790-h.htm">wrote</a>. “One is not getting what one wants, and the other is getting it.” As the US Federal Reserve inches closer to achieving its targets for the domestic economy, it faces growing pressure to normalise monetary policy. But the domestic economy is no longer the Fed’s sole consideration in policymaking. On the contrary, America’s monetary authority has all but explicitly recognised a new mandate: promoting global financial stability.</p><p>The US Congress created the Fed in 1913 as an independent agency removed from partisan politics, tasked with ensuring domestic price stability and maximising domestic employment. Its role has expanded over time, and the Fed, along with many of its developed country counterparts, has engaged in increasingly unconventional monetary policy – quantitative easing, credit easing, forward guidance, and so on – since the 2008 global financial crisis. </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/business/2016/may/05/us-federal-reserve-global-economy-interest-rate-rise">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/business/2016/may/04/us-private-sector-jobs-april-report-slowing-growth</link>
      <description><p>Weak hiring at medium and larger companies and losses in manufacturing account for drop in hires, well short of March’s 194,000 jobs added</p><p>US companies added jobs at the slowest pace in three years in April, a private survey found, a sign that slower growth and volatile financial markets could weigh on hiring.</p><p>Payroll processor ADP says that businesses added 156,000 jobs in April, down from 194,000 in March. Manufacturers shed 11,000 jobs, after losing 3,000 the previous month.       <link>https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2016/may/12/steve-mcelvene-dead-university-of-dayton-basketball</link>
      <description><ul><li>Player had set school record for blocked shots last season</li><li>Cause of death remains unconfirmed after sudden collapse</li></ul><p>The University of Dayton center Steve McElvene has died suddenly at the age of 20, the school has confirmed. A cause of death has not yet been given. </p><p>“We are devastated at this news,” the Dayton coach Archie Miller said in a statement. “Any death is a tragedy, but for someone so young, who worked so hard to have his dreams within reach, it’s hard to put into words how painful this is. Our hearts and prayers go out to Steve’s family. My family, our team and our staff will have to pull together, not only in support of Steve’s family, but in support of each other at this terrible time.”</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2016/may/12/steve-mcelvene-dead-university-of-dayton-basketball">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <title>Jason Day shoots record-equalling round at Players Championship</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2016/may/12/jason-day-sawgrass-players-championship-lowry-rose-spieth-willett</link>
      <description>• Shane Lowry and Justin Rose two behind leader at Sawgrass<br />• Jordan Spieth level-par 72, Danny Willett signs for 70<p>The angst Jordan Spieth suffered by virtue of closing his opening round at the Players Championship with a seven, the one number that may bring him out in a cold sweat, surely intensified with a glance towards one of the his playing partners. Jason Day, who has succeeded Spieth as the world No1, endorsed his status once more with a course record-equalling 63. Day had birdie putts at all 18 holes.</p><p>As Day tapped in for birdie at the 9th, their 18th, Spieth was about to three putt for a double bogey. Spieth’s frustration at a 72 on a day of generally excellent scoring was compounded by that seven; the same scorecard aberration that fatally undermined his hopes of defending the Masters, <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2016/apr/11/danny-willett-masterrs-2016-jordan-spieth-lee-westood" title="">owing to a capitulation at Augusta National’s 12th hole</a>. Spieth later insisted his Thursday score did not appropriately represent his performance. “I really only had two bad swings today,” he said. “I’m hitting the ball great.”</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2016/may/12/jason-day-sawgrass-players-championship-lowry-rose-spieth-willett">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <description><ul><li>Kamara’s transfer comes days after penalty spat with Federico Higuain<br></li><li>Revs GM Michael Burns says: ‘Kei is a proven goalscorer in MLS’<br></li></ul><p>Less than a week after a very public spat with his team-mate over who should take a penalty kick, Columbus Crew have agreed to trade Kei Kamara, last season’s leading goalscorer, to New England Revolution for a record fee.       <link>https://www.theguardian.com/sport/blog/2016/may/12/mannings-most-dominant-american-sports-family</link>
      <description><p>With the retirement of Peyton, the Mannings’ athletic dominance has ended. There are plenty of candidates to fill the void though</p><p>More than three months have passed since Peyton Manning ended his career and Denver’s search for his replacement has been an ongoing story. After Brock Osweiler went to the Texans, the Broncos s<a href="http://espn.go.com/nfl/story/_/id/14951086/denver-broncos-trade-quarterback-mark-sanchez">igned Mark Sanchez</a>, reportedly kicked the tires on Colin Kaepernick, Ryan Fitzpatrick and Sam Bradford, and <a href="http://www.cbssports.com/nfl/eye-on-football/25583365/emmanuel-sanders-tells-paxton-lynch-hes-demaryius-thomas">drafted Paxton Lynch</a>. </p><p>Yet while the Broncos have temporary patched their QB hole with Sanchez and hope to have plugged for the long-term with Lynch, a large and important void remains with an impact stretching far beyond Denver: who is American sport’s reigning power family now? </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/sport/blog/2016/may/12/mannings-most-dominant-american-sports-family">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <title>Why MLS clubs should steer clear of John Terry | Graham Ruthven</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/football/2016/may/12/mls-top-clubs-steer-clear-john-terry</link>
      <description><p>The Chelsea captain is past his best, would cost lots in salary, and do little to dispel the notion of MLS as a retirement home for Europe’s faded stars</p><p>Perhaps John Terry’s American charm offensive started with some words of praise for Chris Wondolowski. Four years ago the Chelsea defender went out of his way to compliment the San Jose striker on his movement throughout the 2012 MLS All-Star game, which Chelsea lost 3-2. Maybe in that moment the former England captain began to think of a life for himself Stateside.</p><p>OK, so Terry probably wasn’t that cynical in his acclaim of Wondolowski, even if his remarks went against the grain of his somewhat toxic caricature. His comments were most likely off the cuff, and maybe even entirely sincere, given the manner in which Wondo so easily lost Terry as he turned home a Thierry Henry cross. With the game played four years ago, the Chelsea man probably wasn’t thinking about a Major League Soccer move just yet.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/football/2016/may/12/mls-top-clubs-steer-clear-john-terry">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Successful women: it’s not only what they do, but what they don’t | Gaby Hinsliff</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2016/may/13/successful-women-pursuit-perfection</link>
      <description>As girls we are taught to do our best and to please others. But the pursuit of perfection has a dark side<p>Do less. Sleep more. Be gentle with yourself. Granted, it’s not exactly a thrusting mantra for success. No minor public school would choose it for a motto, and it’s hardly the stuff of a bestselling time-management book. What ambitious person wants to be told that actually there are only 24 hours in a day, and that sometimes the best way to squeeze more out of them is to stop trying so dementedly hard?</p><p>So it was easy to scoff at the sight of the recently reformed workaholic Arianna Huffington piously advising Hillary Clinton last week to <a href="http://uk.businessinsider.com/arianna-huffington-hillary-clinton-politics-democrat-presidential-2016-4?r=US&amp;IR=T" title="">stop “trying to do everything”</a> and make room for something called “self-care”. Seriously? Right now?</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2016/may/13/successful-women-pursuit-perfection">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Donald Trump supporters are not the bigots the left likes to demonise | John Harris</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2016/may/13/donald-trump-supporters-bigots-left-demonise</link>
      <description>It is time to stop the hysterical moralising and try to understand why mainstream US politics is so unappealing<p>Last Tuesday, at about 3pm, I parked my rental car outside a polling station in the suburbs of Indianapolis, and began to talk to the droves of people going in and out. There was only one subject I really wanted to hear about: <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/us-news/donaldtrump">Donald Trump</a>, and his jaw-dropping progress to being the presumptive Republican nominee.</p><p>As he said himself, a win in the state of Indiana would seal the deal, and <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2016/may/03/trump-wins-indiana-primary-us-election-2016">so it proved</a>: he got 53% of the vote, which triggered the exit of his two supposed rivals. Meanwhile, the global liberal left seemed to be once again working itself into a lather, which was easily translatable: how awful that a man routinely described using all the boo-words progressives can muster – misogynist, racist, fascist, xenophobe, or <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/film/2016/mar/03/george-clooney-donald-trump-is-a-xenophobic-fascist">“xenophobic fascist”</a>, as George Clooney understatedly <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/film/2016/mar/03/george-clooney-donald-trump-is-a-xenophobic-fascist">put it</a> – could now be a resident of the political mainstream, and a serious contender for president.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2016/may/13/donald-trump-supporters-bigots-left-demonise">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <title>Paul Ryan and Donald Trump might say they're unified. But there's a bloody civil war on | Richard Wolffe</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2016/may/12/paul-ryan-donald-trump-republican-unity-battle</link>
      <description><p>Don’t be fooled by the diplomatic words, because peace hasn’t broken out. The Republican power-brokers still loathe Trump, and Ryan is their standard bearer</p><p>When Donald Trump met with Paul Ryan in Washington on Thursday, you could say it was a meeting between the current and possibly future nominee of the Republican party. Or you could say it was a battle for the soul of the party, between a conservative reformer and nativist rabble-rouser.<br></p><p>The latter is how Ryan himself portrayed the debate when he torpedoed the orange flagship on CNN last week. Saying he “just wasn’t ready” to support Trump, the House speaker warned that Trump’s platform was not inclusive, presidential or, well, conservative.<br></p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2016/may/12/paul-ryan-donald-trump-republican-unity-battle">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <title>Antiques Roadshow's jug gaffe vexed me – if only it had been the UK show</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/artanddesign/jonathanjonesblog/2016/may/12/antiques-roadshows-jug-picasso-bbc</link>
      <description><p>The US spinoff’s mistaken valuation shows up what’s wrong with the BBC flagship. Where once the Beeb encouraged art for its own sake, here profit is king</p><p>I have to confess to sheer delight at the mistake made by <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/tv-and-radio/2016/may/11/antiques-roadshow-expert-mistake-school-art-project">a hapless Antiques Roadshow “expert”</a>. Examining a comically primitivist pot brought in for valuation on the popular and venerable television show, appraiser Stephen L Fletcher got quite excited. He identified it as a daring early modernist work from the 19th century. He even discerned “a little bit of, like, <a href="http://www.christies.com/features/Collecting-Picasso-Ceramics-7312-1.aspx">Pablo Picasso</a> going on here”.</p><p> <span>Related: </span><a href="https://www.theguardian.com/tv-and-radio/2016/may/11/antiques-roadshow-expert-mistake-school-art-project">Antiques Roadshow expert mistakenly values school art project at $50,000</a> </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/artanddesign/jonathanjonesblog/2016/may/12/antiques-roadshows-jug-picasso-bbc">Continue reading...</a></description>
      <category domain="https://www.theguardian.com/artanddesign/artanddesign">Art and design</category>
      <category domain="https://www.theguardian.com/artanddesign/art">Art</category>

      <category domain="https://www.theguardian.com/culture/culture">Culture</category>

      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/world/2016/may/12/little-obama-jokes-soviet-era-racism-remains-alive-in-russia</link>
      <description><p>A chocolate bar named ‘Little Obama’ is the latest in a string of offensive images triggered by political tensions</p><p>At the Slavitsa ice cream factory in Russia’s Republic of Tatarstan a decision has been made <a href="http://www.themoscowtimes.com/news/article/russian-company-halts-little-obama-ice-cream-production/569083.html">to discontinue</a> one of its chocolate brands.</p><p>This ordinarily wouldn’t be news, except that these ice cream bars were named after <a href="https://viewer.gutools.co.uk/us-news/barack-obama">Barack Obama</a> and their launch elicited allegations of racism and anti-Americanism from the international community. </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/world/2016/may/12/little-obama-jokes-soviet-era-racism-remains-alive-in-russia">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Hyperloop or over-hyped? Latest demo does little to ease doubts</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2016/may/12/hyperloop-or-over-hyped-latest-demo-does-little-to-ease-doubts</link>
      <description><p>Don’t count your chickens before they’re accelerated at 1,200km an hour down a modified railgun through a vacuum tube</p><p>The future of transportation is here! Deep in the Nevada desert on Wednesday morning, <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2016/may/11/hyperloop-supersonic-train-test-propulsion-system">a linear accelerator propelled a small sled</a> along a purpose-built test track to a speed of almost 187km/h in just over a second. It may just be a very early test but, the assembled media assured us, it means that the Hyperloop – the utopian transport system first mooted by technology entrepreneur Elon Musk – in 2013 is <a draggable="true" href="http://time.com/4325946/hyperloop-one-test/?utm_source=feedburner&amp;utm_medium=feed&amp;utm_campaign=Feed%3A+timeblogs%2Fcurious_capitalist+%28TIME%3A+Business%29">one</a> <a draggable="true" href="http://news.xinhuanet.com/english/2016-05/12/c_135353417.htm">step</a> <a draggable="true" href="http://news.xinhuanet.com/english/2016-05/12/c_135353417.htm">closer</a> <a draggable="true" href="https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/the-switch/wp/2016/05/11/elon-musks-most-ambitious-idea-just-came-one-step-closer-to-reality/">to reality</a>.</p><p>Except, well, it doesn’t. The test shows that Hyperloop One has reached the technological heights of <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Flight_of_Fear">a 1996-era rollercoaster</a> when it comes to its propulsion systems, but does nothing to calm very real doubts that the company will be able to deliver what it promises, when it promises, for the price it promises.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2016/may/12/hyperloop-or-over-hyped-latest-demo-does-little-to-ease-doubts">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <title>Facebook controversy shows journalists are more complicated than algorithms</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2016/may/12/facebook-twitter-google-snapchat-news-bias</link>
      <description><p>Facebook, Twitter, Snapchat and Google have moved outside their comfort zone by trying to curate ‘unbiased’ news – but journalists aren’t like computers</p><p>Silicon Valley is trying to make the news business as neutral as its code. The problem is the humans.<br></p><p>Facebook learned this the hard way this week after a <a href="http://gizmodo.com/former-facebook-workers-we-routinely-suppressed-conser-1775461006">report</a> that staff it contracted to manage its “trending” articles section had suppressed certain stories, such pieces about Facebook or news of interest to conservative users.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2016/may/12/facebook-twitter-google-snapchat-news-bias">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <description><p>Hyperloop One conducts the first public test of a prototype propulsion system which could eventually transport people through tubes at the speed of sound.     <item>
      <title>Who rules the world? America is no longer the obvious answer</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2016/may/09/noam-chomsky-who-rules-the-world-us-foregin-policy</link>
      <description><p>Challenged from all sides, the US is losing its tight grip on international power, <strong>Noam Chomsky </strong>writes, as world public opinion becomes a ‘second superpower’</p><p>When we ask “who rules the world?” we commonly adopt the standard convention that the actors in world affairs are states, primarily the great powers, and we consider their decisions and the relations among them. That is not wrong. But we would do well to keep in mind that this level of abstraction can also be highly misleading.</p><p>States, of course, have complex internal structures, and the choices and decisions of the political leadership are heavily influenced by internal concentrations of power, while the general population is often marginalized. That is true even for the more democratic societies, and obviously for others. We cannot gain a realistic understanding of who rules the world while ignoring the “masters of mankind”, as Adam Smith called them: in his day, the merchants and manufacturers of England; in ours, multinational conglomerates, huge financial institutions, retail empires and the like. </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2016/may/09/noam-chomsky-who-rules-the-world-us-foregin-policy">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <title>Backing bands: which musicians endorse which US presidential candidates?</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2016/feb/01/backing-bands-which-musicians-endorse-which-us-presidential-candidates</link>
      <description><p>Vampire Weekend played a benefit for Bernie Sanders at the weekend, but which other rock stars have declared their intentions? Which candidate has bagged the big names – and is anyone backing Donald Trump?</p><p>As the leftwing choice in 2016, Sanders is not short of rock star fans. <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/music/vampire-weekend">Vampire Weekend</a> played a benefit in Iowa on Saturday (<a href="http://www.nytimes.com/politics/first-draft/2016/01/30/sanders-rallies-iowa-students/">the band were joined by Sanders and his wife Jane</a> for a rendition of Woody Guthrie’s This Land is Your Land), and others will appear at a <a href="http://www.rollingstone.com/music/news/red-hot-chili-peppers-headlining-bernie-sanders-fundraiser-concert-20160127">Feel the Bern fundraiser in Los Angeles on Friday</a>. Headliners will be the <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/music/2016/jan/28/red-hot-chili-peppers-to-headline-bernie-sanders-fundraiser-in-la">Red Hot Chili Peppers</a>, who – presumably after a long band meeting – collectively declared in favour of the Vermont senator last September. “Bernie Sanders is the only remotely reasonable candidate for president of the United States,” Flea had already <a href="https://twitter.com/flea333/status/631623927274467328">tweeted</a> in August. (The Chili Peppers, of course, being longstanding experts on what’s reasonable.)</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2016/feb/01/backing-bands-which-musicians-endorse-which-us-presidential-candidates">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <title>Take it or leave it: Trump's rise puts moderate Republicans in a tough spot</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2016/may/12/moderate-republicans-donald-trump-hillary-clinton</link>
      <description><p>When asked about election day options, many moderate Republicans in Virginia agree on one thing: Trump is appalling but Clinton is an unpalatable alternative<br></p><p>When devoted Republican Lindsay Arthurs walks into a polling booth on 8 November, she will stare at two names on the presidential ballot – Hillary Clinton and Donald Trump – and refuse to choose.</p><p>“It’s not who I want to represent me to the whole world,” she says. “I definitely feel cheated and slighted.”</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2016/may/12/moderate-republicans-donald-trump-hillary-clinton">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>9/11 judge and prosecutors should step down over 'destroyed evidence', defense demands</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2016/may/11/911-khalid-sheikh-mohammed-trial-alleged-destroyed-evidence</link>
      <description><p>Move throws case against Khalid Sheikh Mohammed into chaos as defense team says ‘fatally flawed’ Guantánamo military tribunal should be ended<br></p><p>An explosive allegation about destroyed evidence threatens to unravel the already shaky military tribunal for the alleged architect of the 9/11 terrorist attacks.<br></p><p>Attorneys for Khalid Sheikh Mohammed are calling on the judge and the entire prosecution team in Mohammed’s military commission at Guantánamo Bay to step down from the long-running case over what a member of the defense team called “at least the appearance of collusion” that led to the government apparently secretly destroying information relevant to the premier post-9/11 tribunal.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2016/may/11/911-khalid-sheikh-mohammed-trial-alleged-destroyed-evidence">Continue reading...</a></description>
